thread.title: CD Review: Prokofiev Symphonies 4 & 5, Bournemouth SO/Karabits
thread.title_full: CD Review: Prokofiev Symphonies 4 & 5, Bournemouth SO/Karabits (From Herald Scotland)

author: Michael Tumelty
title: CD Review: Prokofiev Symphonies 4 & 5, Bournemouth SO/Karabits
text:
Prokofiev Symphonies 4 & 5
Bournemouth SO/Karabits
Onyx
Share article KIRILL Karabits’ Prokofiev Symphonies series with the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra grows apace. We’ve already had the First, Second, Third and Seventh Symphonies, along with the Sinfonietta. Now the series is extended with the Fourth Symphony, given in its original 1930 version, and the ultimate Prokofiev symphonic warhorse, the overwhelming Fifth Symphony, once a great concert showstopper, though we don’t seem to hear it so much in these parts at this time. Karabits’ is a good, strong, sturdy series, packed with integrity, somewhat at the cost of the sheer elan of the music – he seems keen on understating the “factory-floor clatter” in the finale of the Fifth Symphony, and underplaying the mechanistic mayhem of the coda in that movement. There is also a lovely account of the atmospheric Dreams, an early, rather neglected piece, while the Fourth Symphony, perhaps a little too-respectfully treated here, will remain forever a matter of debate: “Is it a proper symphony or a ballet suite in disguise?
Michael Tumelty
